results.headline: A Meditation on Captivity, Featuring an Orangutan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nenette

results.summary_short: The voices of visitors to a Paris zoo serve as a soundtrack to Nicolas Philibert’s new film.

results.headline: A Man’s Slow Suicidal Walk to Starvation in the Forest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sound of Insects

results.summary_short: “The Sound of Insects” is adapted from a novel based on the real diary of a man who decided to commit suicide by starving himself to death.

results.headline: Patriarch Faces Future: Who to Lead Nutty Clan When He Is Gone?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Fockers

results.summary_short: In “Little Fockers,” the addition of children and the passage of time lead Jack (Robert De Niro) to wonder if Greg (Ben Stiller) is ready to step into his role.

results.headline: Jellystone Gets Animated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yogi Bear

results.summary_short: “Yogi Bear” stars Dan Aykroyd and Justin Timberlake as the denizens of Jellystone.

results.headline: Following in Father’s Parallel-Universe Footsteps

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tron: Legacy

results.summary_short: “Tron: Legacy,” Disney’s 3-D sequel to the 1982 “Tron,” picks up with far less color and cinematic imagination, and many more bells and whistles.

results.headline: Charades of Normalcy After Death of a Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rabbit Hole

results.summary_short: In “Rabbit Hole” Nicole Kidman and Aaron Eckhart play grieving parents whose 4-year-old son has died.

results.headline: Disappointed in Softball, but Will She Be Disappointed in Love?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How Do You Know

results.summary_short: Reese Witherspoon stars in a comedy written and directed by James L. Brooks.

results.headline: Want a Deal on a Used Country?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Casino Jack

results.summary_short: “Casino Jack,” starring Kevin Spacey, tells the story of Jack Abramoff.

results.headline: In My Father’s House, That Airless, Bitter Place

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mundane History

results.summary_short: Anocha Suwichakornpong’s feature debut, “Mundane History,” is a spare family drama told through strong, purposeful images.

results.headline: Let a Hail of Bullets Be Your Umbrella

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vengeance

results.summary_short: Johnnie To crams enough terror, tears and choreographed action into “Vengeance” for a half-dozen films. And that’s just in the first 15 minutes.

results.headline: Guys, Kiss Mom and Come Out Fighting

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fighter

results.summary_short: Mark Wahlberg and Christian Bale are brothers in the new David O. Russell film “The Fighter.”

results.headline: Visiting an Ordinarily Unique Artist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of And Everything Is Going Fine

results.summary_short: “And Everything Is Going Fine” shows performances by Spalding Gray, a man sitting at a table being entertaining.

results.headline: Perils of the Corporate Ladder: It Hurts When You Fall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Company Men

results.summary_short: Ben Affleck and Chris Cooper play characters who learn that, in a company concerned about the bottom line, almost everyone is expendable.

results.headline: Misfit’s Life of Exaggeration

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Won't Miss Me

results.summary_short: With “You Wont Miss Me,” Stella Schnabel and the director Ry Russo-Young relay the strangely compelling story of a New York misfit.

results.headline: Gallivanting Across Europe in High Heels and High Dudgeon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tourist

results.summary_short: Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp star in a thriller set in Europe, where an American visitor falls in with a gorgeous woman of questionable motives.

results.headline: Dread Rattling Thunder! Yes, It’s Shakespeare

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tempest

results.summary_short: Julie Taymor brings her theatrical exuberance to a new film version of “The Tempest.”

results.headline: In the South of France, a 1927 Ménage à Trois Takes an Incendiary Turn

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hemingway's Garden of Eden

results.summary_short: “Hemingway’s Garden of Eden” is an adaptation of Hemingway’s problematic erotic novel, posthumously published in 1986.

results.headline: Enchanted Realm, Aquatic View
results.display_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader

results.summary_short: Directed by Michael Apted, this third “Narnia” film takes its crew of children, animals and wizards to the high seas.

results.headline: Bystanders to China’s Transition

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beijing Taxi

results.summary_short: The filmmaker Miao Wang follows three cabbies in “Beijing Taxi,” her documentary about working-class Chinese life.

results.headline: The Hippie Serving Peace and Breakfast
results.display_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie

results.summary_short: “Saint Misbehavin’” documents the life and roots of Wavy Gravy, an authentic unreconstructed hippie idealist.
